natural problem: Compute the least common multiple of $9999$ and $100{,}001$.
natural solution: Recall the identity $\mathop{\text{lcm}}[a,b]\cdot \gcd(a,b)=ab$, which holds for all positive integers $a$ and $b$.

Therefore, any common divisor of $100001$ and $9999$ must be a divisor of $100001-10\cdot 9999 = 11$. The possibilities are $1$ and $11$. In fact, $9999=11\cdot 909$, so $11$ is a divisor of $9999$ and $100001$, which gives $\gcd(9999,100001) = 11$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 9999"
and h1 : "b = 100001"
shows  "lcm a b = 90900909"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the least common multiple of $9999$ and $100{,}001$. The final Answer is 90{,}900{,}909
 ### Proof
 Recall the identity $\mathop{\text{lcm}}[a,b]\cdot \gcd(a,b)=ab$, which holds for all positive integers $a$ and $b$.
 Thus, $$\mathop{\text{lcm}}[9999,100001] = \frac{9999\cdot 100001}{\gcd(9999,100001)},$$so we focus on computing $\gcd(9999,100001)$. Notice that $100001 = 99990+11 = 10(9999)+11$.
 Therefore, any common divisor of $100001$ and $9999$ must be a divisor of $100001-10\cdot 9999 = 11$. The possibilities are $1$ and $11$. In fact, $9999=11\cdot 909$, so $11$ is a divisor of $9999$ and $100001$, which gives $\gcd(9999,100001) = 11$.
 Therefore, \begin{align} \mathop{\text{lcm}}[9999,100001] &= \frac{9999\cdot 100001}{11} \\ &= 909\cdot 100001 \\ &= 909\cdot 100000 + 909 \\ &= \boxed{90{,}900{,}909}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 9999"
and h1 : "b = 100001"
shows  "lcm a b = 90900909"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the least common multiple (LCM) of the numbers 9999 and 100001. The final answer is 90900909.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b lcm :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 9999"
and h1 : "b = 100001"
and h2 : "lcm = \<lambda> a b. \<exists> m n. m * a = n * b \<and> m \<ge> a \<and> n \<ge> b"
shows  "lcm a b = 90900909"
a_3.formal solution:

 Therefore, \begin{align} \mathop{\text{lcm}}[9999,100001] &= \frac{9999\cdot 100001}{11} \\ &= 909\cdot 100001 \\ &= 909\cdot 100000 + 909 \\ &= \boxed{90{,}900{,}909}. \end{align}
 *)
